title: 107_hr3920
content: The "Rancher Preservation Act" is the short title of this Act. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include special requirements regarding the black-tailed prairie dog. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require the use of the best scientific and commercial data available when determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. This includes giving greater weight to empirical or peer-reviewed data and considering population numbers of the species. The Secretary must base any determination on the status of the black-tailed prairie dog on field observation data and accept information from landowners collected through observation on their land. The Secretary must base any determination on the status of the black-tailed prairie dog on field observation data from landowners and include this data in the rulemaking record for endangered or threatened species. Independent scientific review requirements define actions related to the species status determinations. The black-tailed prairie dog's status determination must be based on field observation data from landowners and included in the rulemaking record for endangered or threatened species. A qualified individual is defined as someone with expertise in biological sciences, demonstrated through scientific literature publication on the black-tailed prairie dog or similar species. A qualified individual for the decision of the Secretary under section 4(a) or (f) must have scientific expertise relevant to the species, no conflict of interest, not be a participant in any petition or determination, and have no direct financial interests. The Secretary must appoint independent scientific reviewers who have no financial interest in opposing the action under consideration. The National Academy of Sciences will provide recommendations for qualified reviewers. Before finalizing any action, the Secretary must appoint 3 qualified individuals to review and report on the scientific information. Reviewers will be compensated for their independent review. The selection and activities of the reviewers are not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary must appoint 3 qualified individuals for an independent review of scientific information on the black-tailed prairie dog. Reviewers will provide their opinion within 3 months, and the Secretary will consider their recommendations in the final determination. The independent scientific review for the black-tailed prairie dog must be summarized and included in the final determination. The report of the peer reviewers will be part of the official record and available for public review before the comment period closes. The comment period on the proposed action is being amended by striking the item relating to section 13 and inserting a new section. Special requirements for black-tailed prairie dog are being amended in a new section.
